Award.AwardTitle: Physics of Living Systems at StatPhys27
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support the participation of researchers working on the Physics of Living Systems (PoLS) at the 27th International Conference on Statistical Physics, StatPhys27, which will be held in Buenos Aires, Argentina in July 2019. It is expected that StatPhys27 will bring together about 700 participants from all over the world, including senior and young researchers and graduate students. Statistical Physics is largely interdisciplinary, so that the participation of researchers with diverse scientific backgrounds is expected. StatPhys27 will last for five days. Associated to StatPhys27 there will be an outreach activity with three talks for the general public at the National Science Museum. Two of the talks will be in the field of PoLS. There will also be sessions on human rights and on inclusion and diversity in physics and an outreach activity for the general public. Taking active part in StatPhys27 will allow the researchers working in the field of PoLS to reach out to new communities of students and researchers. The plenary talks of StatPhys27 will be videotaped and made available at the conference website. The possibility of streaming them live over the Internet is under consideration. The International Centre for Theoretical Physics of Trieste (ICTP) has offered to set up a special conference room at its premises where people could watch the video-streaming. Thus, StatPhys27 is expected to have a huge impact in various places. Furthermore, the outreach activity that is planned to take place at the Science Museum in Buenos Aires will allow the general public to learn about the subjects of statistical physics and the physics of living systems.

StatPhys is the largest and most prestigious conference on the nowadays broadly interdisciplinary area of statistical physics. Held triennially in different parts of the world, it attracts most of the community that does research on the subject. Ten renowned scientists will give plenary talks and another 30 will do so at one of the four planned parallel sessions of StatPhys27. The conference will also host the Boltzmann Medal and Young Scientist in Statistical Physics ceremonies. The recipient of the prestigious Boltzmann Medal will give a plenary talk. StatPhys27 will embrace a variety of subjects including Physics of Living Systems, Complex and Interdisciplinary Systems, Soft Matter, Out-of-equilibrium phenomena and Nonlinear Physics, etc.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project helped American scientists travel abroad to the StatPhys27 conference in Argentina. StatPhys is one of the top international conferences in the Statistical Mechanics area. 

From its very beginning, the quantitative study of biological systems involved the use of concepts drawn from thermodynamics and statistical physics such as chemical potential and free energy. Even though these concepts proved to be useful, they were mainly introduced to describe systems in thermodynamic equilibrium while living systems are far from equilibrium. Recent theoretical developments have extended thermodynamic concepts, which apply to systems composed of innumerous particles, to the individual stochastic trajectories of these individual components. These theoretical developments constitute the body of what is now known as stochastic thermodynamics and have led to a continuous interplay between theory and experiments in which single biomolecules are manipulated and observed in their native environment. This is not the only aspect in which statistical physics and biological systems are closely intertwined. The massive amount of data that biological experiments have been generating in the past decades has led to the development of new techniques of data analysis and of data-driven models that make a very strong use of statistical physics tools. This close connection between statistical and biological physics is reflected, among other things, on the numerous contributions on biological problems that are presented in publications and conferences on statistical physics. The Conference on Statistical Physics of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics, StatPhys, is one such example. 

Organized triennially, the StatPhys conferences attract the vast majority of the statistical physics community across the world including senior and young researchers and graduate students. Tackling biological problems has increased within the discipline of statistical physics. This is reflected in its main conference, StatPhys, where at least 5 of its 8 topics (Out of equilibrium aspects, Biological Physics, Soft Matter, Nonlinear Physics and Interdisciplinary and Complex Systems) include results on living systems and related subjects. StatPhys27 was held in Buenos Aires, Argentina on July 8-12, 2019 (https://statphys27.df.uba.ar/) for the first time in its 70 years of history. The conference had a huge impact in the region. This is reflected in the 11 satellite meetings that were organized before and after StatPhys27 in Argentina, Brazil and Chile. The last StatPhys was held in Lyon, France, and  with 1300 participants from over 50 different countries. The number of participants of StatPhys27 in Buenos Aires was over 700. In this project we proposed to use this unique opportunity to advance the goals of the Physics of Living Systems Network, in particular, to help expose students from all over the world to the most recent results on biological physics, to advertise the existence of the PoLS network and to eventually enlarge it by attracting other physics PhD programs to it.
